description: Borrowed from Latin tāctus. Sense “keen perception” developed in French tact.

examples: Now, sight is a very refined tact.

entries.meaning: Sensitive mental touch; special skill or faculty; keen perception or discernment; ready power of appreciating and doing what is required by circumstances; the ability to say the right thing. [from early 19th c.]

examples: Wanda "Hey, can you show us?"Karen "No"Brent "We promise not to make fun of you."Karen "No"Lacey "Okay, we promise TO make fun of you."Karen "I'm getting a drink"Lacey "I was trying a different tact."Wanda "Bad tack."

entries.meaning: (psychology) A verbal operant which is controlled by a nonverbal stimulus (such as an object, event, or property of an object) and is maintained by nonspecific social reinforcement (praise).
examples: Skinner (1957) saw such tacts as responses that are reinforced socially.

verbs.description: tact (third-person singular simple present tacts, present participle tacting, simple past and past participle tacted)

entries.meaning: (psychology) To use a tact (a kind of verbal operant; see noun sense).
